learning_outcomes.description: Understand and describe properties of selected biomedical signals, including how these may affect related clinical applications.
Identify appropriate solutions for specific problems in biomedical engineering by considering the benefits and limitations of various digital signal processing approaches.
Implement signal processing algorithms for practical problems involving biomedical signals.
Analyse selected physiological data with a particular focus on detecting events in biomedical signals.
Demonstrate the need for digital signal processing in certain medical devices and clinical procedures.
Propose, carry out, orally present, and report in conference-proceedings format, a research project on biomedical signal processing.

Critically analyse information independently acquired from diverse sources (e.g., the Internet, books, electronic application notes, company product data sheets, databases such as the ISI Web of Science and IEEExplore) in providing solutions to real-world clinical biomedical signal analysis problems.

assessments.task_description: The project regards the first module in the course (spectral analysis). The project involves developing computer code to analyse the given data and reproduce the results of the selected paper. Students formulate code, code is being run and checked, submit a short report, and then undergo a brief (e.g., 5–10 min) oral exam to demonstrate their code and verify that it is theirs and that they understand it. Students will sign up for a time from available sessions in the week immediately following the submission deadline to demonstrate their code. This will likely be outside of the normal scheduled class time.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments are to be submitted online via Blackboard unless otherwise specified for a particular assessment item. The data, codes, and report will be in a single zip file with the student's name and student ID.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.category: Computer Code, Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Tutorial/ Problem Set

assessments.task_description: Students will be required to write a 2-page conference paper about one of the three projects and seat for an oral exam (e.g., 5- 10 min). Students will sign up for a time from available sessions in the week immediately following the submission deadline to demonstrate their code. This will likely be outside of the normal scheduled class time. Students can choose which project they would like to use. The format of the project guidelines (template).

learning_activities.topic:
Projects

Each main module of the course will feature an individual project where biomedical signal processing methods and real-world data are used.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
